div.p: This plugin allows users to interact with the Internet Information Services (IIS) server version 7 and accomplish tasks such as managing servers, web sites, and virtual directories.

Supported IIS version
This plugin was developed and tested with IIS 7.0.
To enable Commander to communicate with your IIS installation, create a IIS configuration, supplying the following information:

ul.li: Configuration Name - Provide a unique name for the configuration, keeping in mind that you may need to create additional configurations over time.
IIS IP Address - Provide the URL for the IIS server, it must include the protocol (example: http://192.168.1.100).
IIS Port - Provide the port for the IIS server (example: 8081).
Computer Name - Provide the computer name or IP address without backslashes (for example: server01 or 192.168.1.100).

Credential - Provide the username and password for the IIS server. Note: Credentials are optional. Supplying credentials for a "local" agent (an agent on the same machine as the IIS server) is unnecessary, and in some cases will generate a 'warning' condition.

div.p: See the Commander online help systemfor details about how to use this plugin within a procedure.
This procedure checks the status of the specified server.

ul.li: configname - Provide the name of the configuration that holds connection information for the IIS server. In this case, only credentials are taken from the configuration.
usecredentials - Indicate if credentials must be used.

div.p: This procedure creates a new virtual directory in the specified web site.

ul.li: appname - Provide the web site and virtual path that contains the virtual directory you want to create, for example: "Default Web Site/" or "Site1/myapp".
physicalpath - Provide the absolute physical path of the virtual directory you want to create, for example: c:/Inetpub/wwwroot/myvdir
path - Provide the virtual path of the virtual directory, for examplag: /myvirtualdir

div.p: This procedure deletes a virtual directory from the specified web site.

ul.li: appname - Provide the web site and virtual path that contains the virtual directory you want to delete, for example: "Default Web Site/" or "Site1/myapp".

div.p: This procedure assigns an application to an application pool.

ul.li: appname - Provide the name of the application you want to assign.
apppoolname - Provide the name of the application pool you want to assign to the application.
sitename - Provide the name of the site that contains the application you want to assign.

div.p: This procedure verifies if an application pool exists. If it does not, an IIS application pool is created.

ul.li: appname - Provide the name of the application pool you want to create.

div.p: This procedure starts an IIS application pool.

ul.li: appname - Provide the name of the application pool you want to start.

div.p: This procedure stops an IIS application pool.

ul.li: appname - Provide the name of the application pool you want to stop.

div.p: This procedure starts a web site in an IIS server.

ul.li: sitename - Provide the descriptive name, or the metabase path, of the web site you want to start.

div.p: This procedure stops a web site.

ul.li: sitename - Provide the descriptive name, or the metabase path, of the web site you want to stop.

div.p: This procedure adds an application in IIS 7.

ul.li: appname - Provide the web site that contains the application you want to create, for example: "Default Web Site/" or "Site1/myapp".

div.p: This procedure deletes a web application from the specified web site.

ul.li: appname - Provide the web site that contains the application you want to delete, for example: "Default Web Site/" or "Site1/myapp".

div.p: This procedure lists a web site's applications.

ul.li: sitename - Provide the name of the site to look for applications.

div.p: This procedure lists sites available in an IIS installation.

ul.li: searchcriteria - Provide user-defined criteria to search the sites, for example: "/bindings:http/*:80:". Leave blank to list all sites.

div.p: Blank lists all sites copies application files recursively to the web site application's physical directory.

ul.li: ExecPath - Provide the relative or absolute path to the XCOPY (or similar) executable.
SourcePath - Provide the path to the source directory.
DestinationPath - Provide the path to the destination directory. This must be a physical directory, but it can have an IIS virtual directory pointing to it.

AdditionalOptions - Indicate option switches for the XCOPY executable, excluding source and destination directories. The default options are those recommended by Microsoft for ASP.NET and IIS web site deployment; exercise caution when changing these options.
/E - Deep copy including empty dirs
/K - Copy attributes
/R - Overwrite read-only files
/H - Copy hidden and system files
/I - If destination does not exist and copying more than one file, assumes that destination must be a directory
/Y - Suppress prompting for overwrite confirmation
